contents.workSub: The new website significantly improves professional credibility, user clarity, and conversion readiness compared to the legacy site.
contents.leftText: Clearer value proposition for target audiences
contents.midText: Stronger visual hierarchy and brand trust signals
contents.rightText: More intentional user paths and calls to action

issue1: Content is mostly linear text blocks and hinders readability.
Weak hierarchy: headings, body text, and supporting details visually blend together.
Little use of spacing to separate ideas → high cognitive load.
Lacking modern design causes low perceived trust for a cybersecurity/compliance business.
impr1: Clear sectioning with visible breaks between ideas.
Stronger hierarchy: Hero headline → subheadline → supporting copy → CTA.
Better use of whitespace to reduce cognitive load.
Sections feel scannable rather than dense.
Visual elements (icons, same style logos) reinforce professionalism
issue2: Single or limited font usage with minimal hierarchy.
Font sizes are similar across headings and paragraphs.
impr2: Clear typographic hierarchy: Large hero headline; Medium section headers; Smaller supporting text.
Text is more readable at a glance.
issue3: No strong brand identity or emotional signal.
Feels more like a technical reference than a trusted service brand.
impr3: Stronger brand tone: Blue/neutral palette reinforces trust and security.
Icons and visual markers support comprehension.
Overall look aligns better with B2B cybersecurity expectations.
issue4: Navigation labels have a flat structure with little guidance. Users must read content to understand relevance.
No obvious prioritization of user goals.
impr4: Content organized by user type and intent.
“Schedule a Call” surfaced as a global action to enhance conversion.
issue5: Benefits and guarantees are buried in paragraphs. Difficult to skim.
Users may abandon before key points. And they are unsure “Is this for me?”
impr5: Uses audience segmentation early and explicit audience targeting (DoD contractors, SMBs).
Brings benefits closer to the top of the page.
Persuasive page flow (target audience → benefits → price → CTA) leads to faster comprehension and better alignment with decision-maker mental models.
More visuals to make the page seem inviting.
issue6: CTAs are passive (“Contact us”). It waits for users to initiate the conversation.
Contact info only appears at the bottom of each page.
impr6: Primary CTA (“Schedule a Call”) is prominent on the global header.
“Contact Us” is on the top navigation bar for more user attention.
“Contact Us” form invites users to send their feedback or requests proactively at any time.
issue7: Trust signals exist but are buried.
impr7: Trust signals (standards, compliance logos) are more visible on the homepage.
Trust signals combined with “Why we’re different” are more persuasive.
Clearer information displayed with short description of “Why we’re different”.
